text:
Ashitha Nagesh for Metro.co.uk Friday 3 Feb 2017 10:06 am Uber’s CEO has quit Trump’s advisory board (Picture: Shutterstock) 
After widespread outcry and calls for an international boycott, Uber’s CEO has stepped down from Donald Trump’s economic advisory board. 
People all over the world pledged to #DeleteUber in response to Travis Kalanick’s place on the board, as well as to the company’s perceived attempt to break the picket line of the New York taxi strike at JFK airport. 
Kalanick has said Uber is one of many companies concerned about President Trump’s ban on people from seven Muslim-majority countries. 
The company also said it was setting up a $3million (£2.39million) legal fund to help those affected – which likely includes many of its own drivers. Travis Kalanick stepped down in a memo to staff (Picture: Getty Images) 
‘Joining the [advisory] group was not meant to be an endorsement of the president or his agenda, but unfortunately it has been misinterpreted to be exactly that,’ Kalanick said in a staff memo, which was seen by the BBC . Man successfully sues stepmother for share of £2.9 million lottery win 
‘The implicit assumption that Uber (or I) was somehow endorsing the Administration’s agenda has created a perception-reality gap between who people think we are, and who we actually are.’ 
But Uber wasn’t the only business to suffer from its association with Trump – who is empirically the least popular President in the US’s history. 
US retailer Nordstrom has announced that it will stop carrying Ivanka Trump’s brand as a direct result of declining sales. Sales of her stuff had been dropping (Picture: Getty Images) 
‘Each year we cut about 10% [of brands carried] and refresh our assortment with about the same amount,’ a Nordstrom spokesperson told Business Insider . Girl, 14, dies after being thrown from spinning fairground ride 
‘In this case, based on the brand’s performance, we’ve decided not to buy it for this season.’ 
Critics of Trump’s administration have been calling for major boycotts of any company or retailer with business ties to the President and his family. 
An app – Boycott Trump – has surged in popularity since the President’s first week, in which he enacted a series of extreme executive orders. More
